claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.

extracted_evidence.quote: For the 2024-2025 influenza season it is formulated to contain 135 mcg HA per 0.5 mL dose, with 45 mcg HA of each of the following 3 influenza virus strains: A/West Virginia/30/2022 (A/Wisconsin/67/2022 pdm09-like virus) (H1N1), A/Massachusetts/18/2022 (H3N2) and B/Austria/1359417/2021.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote provides the exact hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content per dose in Flublok, showing it contains 45 mcg HA per strain, for a total of 135 mcg HA per dose, which is three times the standard 15 mcg HA per strain in standard-dose flu vaccines.

extracted_evidence.quote: 5. Treanor JJ, Schiff GM, Hayden FG, et al. Safety and immunogenicity of a baculovirus-expressed hemagglutinin influenza vaccine: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Vol. 297, pp. 1577-1582.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference is cited in the context of clinical studies comparing the immunogenicity of Flublok (which contains 3x the HA antigen) to standard-dose flu vaccines, directly supporting the link between higher HA content and greater immunogenicity.

extracted_evidence.quote: 3. Keitel WA, Treanor JJ, El Sahly HM, et al. Comparative immunogenicity of recombinant influenza hemagglutinin (rHA) and trivalent inactivated vaccines (TIVs) among persons ≥65 years old. Vaccine 2009 Vol. 28, pp. 379–385.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference is included in the list of clinical studies and specifically addresses comparative immunogenicity between Flublok (with higher HA content) and standard-dose vaccines, supporting the claim that increased HA content is linked to greater immunogenicity.
